Appendix

VI-A Proof of Theorem 1

Recall that there is a list of uùë¢u blocks, <Ry1,‚Ä¶,Ryu><R_{y_{1}},\ldots,R_{y_{u}}>, where each block is a set of records. We need to show that if each block is maximum-score w-ordered and the scoring heuristic fùëìf is local, then the ordered list of records is both necessary and sufficient for max SN.

From Section IV, the w-score of any such list is the score of the candidate set ŒìŒì\Gamma generated after the list is subject to the w-window merge step. Per Definition 4, max SN will always perform merge on a list that guarantees maximum w-score, compared to any other list that obeys SN semantics. Let such a list, RlsuperscriptùëÖùëôR^{l}, be denoted as the max list. We assume in this proof that the total number of records in RùëÖR is strictly greater than wùë§w, since otherwise, every list would yield the same w-score and max SN would be trivially achieved.

When the merge step commences on the max list, all records within a window of size wùë§w are paired and added to the candidate set ŒìŒì\Gamma. There is an alternate way of characterizing ŒìŒì\Gamma. Specifically, partition ŒìŒì\Gamma into a set of (at most) 2‚Äãu2ùë¢2u sets, two for each block. Let the it‚Äãhsuperscriptùëñùë°‚Ñéi^{th} block contribute two disjoint sets ŒìisubscriptŒìùëñ\Gamma_{i} and Œìi0superscriptsubscriptŒìùëñ0\Gamma_{i}^{0}. The reason for the 0 superscript will become clear shortly.

The partition is achieved by the following construction:

  1. 1.

    If both records in a pair {r,s}‚ààŒìùëüùë†Œì\{r,s\}\in\Gamma are from the same block RyisubscriptùëÖsubscriptùë¶ùëñR_{y_{i}}, place {r,s}ùëüùë†\{r,s\} in set ŒìisubscriptŒìùëñ\Gamma_{i}.

  2. 2.

    If the records in a pair {r,s}‚ààŒìùëüùë†Œì\{r,s\}\in\Gamma are from different blocks (say r‚ààRyiùëüsubscriptùëÖsubscriptùë¶ùëñr\in R_{y_{i}} and s‚ààRyjùë†subscriptùëÖsubscriptùë¶ùëós\in R_{y_{j}}), then add {r,s}ùëüùë†\{r,s\} to Œìi0superscriptsubscriptŒìùëñ0\Gamma_{i}^{0} if i<jùëñùëói<j otherwise add the pair to Œìj0superscriptsubscriptŒìùëó0\Gamma_{j}^{0}.

Some of the sets may be empty; we remove them from the partition if so, and thereby fulfill the conditions of a partition. Using the partition:

Œì=‚ãÉi=1uŒìi‚à™‚ãÉi=1uŒìi0Œìsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùë¢subscriptŒìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùë¢superscriptsubscriptŒìùëñ0\Gamma=\bigcup_{i=1}^{u}\Gamma_{i}\cup\bigcup_{i=1}^{u}\Gamma_{i}^{0} (2)

By Definition 2 of the local scoring heuristic, the score of each pair in Œìi0superscriptsubscriptŒìùëñ0\Gamma_{i}^{0} is 0 (hence, the superscript). Thus, the score of ŒìŒì\Gamma is only contributed to by the first term in Equation 2. Since each of the sets operated upon by union is disjoint, the following equation is directly derived:

s‚Äãc‚Äão‚Äãr‚Äãe‚Äã(Œì)=‚àëi=1us‚Äãc‚Äão‚Äãr‚Äãe‚Äã(Œìi)ùë†ùëêùëúùëüùëíŒìsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùë¢ùë†ùëêùëúùëüùëísubscriptŒìùëñscore(\Gamma)=\sum_{i=1}^{u}score(\Gamma_{i}) (3)

Again, because of disjointness, taking the max on both sides allows us to move the max inside the summation in Equation 3. By the semantics of Algorithm 1 and Definition 3 of maximum-score w-ordering, max s‚Äãc‚Äão‚Äãr‚Äãe‚Äã(Œìi)ùë†ùëêùëúùëüùëísubscriptŒìùëñscore(\Gamma_{i}) exactly equals the maximum w-score achievable over all orderings of the block RyisubscriptùëÖsubscriptùë¶ùëñR_{y_{i}}. Thus, the condition that every block is independently maximum-score w-ordered is a sufficient one for maximizing the score of ŒìŒì\Gamma.

We prove necessity by contradiction. Suppose some block RyisubscriptùëÖsubscriptùë¶ùëñR_{y_{i}} is not maximum-score w-ordered. Let its list version (of which the w-score will not be maximized per Algorithm 1) be RyilsubscriptsuperscriptùëÖùëôsubscriptùë¶ùëñR^{l}_{y_{i}}. Let the candidate set generated as a result be Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime}, and assume ŒìŒì\Gamma to be the generated candidate set if RyisubscriptùëÖsubscriptùë¶ùëñR_{y_{i}} were maximum-score w-ordered. We assume Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime} was generated from a max list and show that this leads to a contradiction. Using Equation 3 and the construction of the partition, the difference between the scores of ŒìŒì\Gamma and Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime} will be s‚Äãc‚Äão‚Äãr‚Äãe‚Äã(Œìi)‚àís‚Äãc‚Äão‚Äãr‚Äãe‚Äã(Œìi‚Ä≤)ùë†ùëêùëúùëüùëísubscriptŒìùëñùë†ùëêùëúùëüùëísubscriptsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤ùëñscore(\Gamma_{i})-score(\Gamma^{\prime}_{i}). Since RyisubscriptùëÖsubscriptùë¶ùëñR_{y_{i}} was maximum-score w-ordered in the list that generated ŒìŒì\Gamma but not Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime}, the difference is positive. If we replace list RyilsubscriptsuperscriptùëÖùëôsubscriptùë¶ùëñR^{l}_{y_{i}} with another list that achieves higher w-score, the score of Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime} will monotonically improve. This proves the contradiction, since Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime} was clearly not generated from a max list.

Thus, if any block is non-maximum-score w-ordered, the resulting global list of records will not be a max list. The contrapositive of the statement proves necessity. Coupled with the proof for sufficience, the full statement of the theorem is proved.

VI-B Proof of Theorem 3

Theorem 2 showed that maximum-score 2-ordering was NP-complete; hence, it suffices to show a Karp reduction from the decision version of maximum-score 2-ordering on a set RùëÖR of records. Let |R|=mùëÖùëö|R|=m; RùëÖR consists of records {r1,‚Ä¶,rm}subscriptùëü1‚Ä¶subscriptùëüùëö\{r_{1},\ldots,r_{m}\}. We also assume that m>>wmuch-greater-thanùëöùë§m>>w.

We begin by constructing a new set SùëÜS of m‚Äã(w‚àí1)ùëöùë§1m(w-1) records, by mapping each record ri‚ààRsubscriptùëüùëñùëÖr_{i}\in R to a set SisubscriptùëÜùëñS_{i} which contains w‚àí1ùë§1w-1 records. Let SisubscriptùëÜùëñS_{i} be denoted as an internal set and iùëñi as the set ID of SisubscriptùëÜùëñS_{i}. Also, let each record in this set be denoted as sijsuperscriptsubscriptùë†ùëñùëós_{i}^{j}, where j‚àà{1,2,‚Ä¶,w‚àí1}ùëó12‚Ä¶ùë§1j\in\{1,2,\ldots,w-1\} and is the internal ID of the record. SùëÜS is simply the union of all the mùëöm internal sets that the records were mapped to.

Technically, such a construction can be achieved by assigning SùëÜS a schema containing just two attributes (called set ID and internal ID). Each record in SùëÜS can be uniquely identified by employing both IDs in conjunction; hence, both IDs together constitute a compound primary key.

We obtain a new scoring heuristic f‚Ä≤superscriptùëì‚Ä≤f^{\prime} for record pairs in SùëÜS using the following construction:

  1. 1.

    f‚Ä≤‚Äã(sic,sid)=12‚Äã‚àëu=1m‚àëv=1mf‚Äã(ru,rv)superscriptùëì‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùë†ùëñùëêsuperscriptsubscriptùë†ùëñùëë12superscriptsubscriptùë¢1ùëösuperscriptsubscriptùë£1ùëöùëìsubscriptùëüùë¢subscriptùëüùë£f^{\prime}(s_{i}^{c},s_{i}^{d})=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{u=1}^{m}\sum_{v=1}^{m}f(r_{u},r_{v}), ‚àÄi‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,m}for-allùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëö\forall i\in\{1,\ldots,m\} and ‚àÄc,d‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,w‚àí1}for-allùëêùëë1‚Ä¶ùë§1\forall c,d\in\{1,\ldots,w-1\}

  2. 2.

    f‚Ä≤‚Äã(sic,sjc)=f‚Äã(ri,rj)superscriptùëì‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùë†ùëñùëêsuperscriptsubscriptùë†ùëóùëêùëìsubscriptùëüùëñsubscriptùëüùëóf^{\prime}(s_{i}^{c},s_{j}^{c})=f(r_{i},r_{j}), ‚àÄi,j‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,m},i‚â†jformulae-sequencefor-allùëñùëó1‚Ä¶ùëöùëñùëó\forall i,j\in\{1,\ldots,m\},i\neq j and ‚àÄc‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,w‚àí1}for-allùëê1‚Ä¶ùë§1\forall c\in\{1,\ldots,w-1\}

  3. 3.

    f‚Ä≤=0superscriptùëì‚Ä≤0f^{\prime}=0 for all other record pairs

Intuitively, Rule 1 uniformly assigns the same large score to the record pairs that lie within the same internal set, independent of the specific internal or set IDs of records161616This is evident when we consider that the variables on the left hand side of Rule 1 are independent of the variables on the right hand side. If we visualize the scoring heuristic fùëìf as a discrete m√ómùëöùëöm\times m matrix (but with diagonal entries undefined; see Definition 2), the quantity on the right hand side is simply the sum of all (defined) matrix entries. The factor of 1/2 is to prevent each entry from being counted twice, due to the symmetry of the two summations.

Rule 2 shows that a non-zero score can only exist between the ct‚Äãhsuperscriptùëêùë°‚Ñéc^{th} records of two different internal sets (with cùëêc ranging from 1 to w‚àí1ùë§1w-1) and is equal to the score between the original records that were mapped to the two sets in the construction. Note that the score itself is independent of the value of cùëêc. Rule 3 assigns every other record pair in the scaled problem a score of zero.

Thus, Rule 1 applies when two records belong to the same internal set (and have the same set ID), while Rule 2 applies when two records have different set IDs but the same internal ID. Otherwise, Rule 3 applies.

The computation of f‚Ä≤superscriptùëì‚Ä≤f^{\prime} occurs in polynomial time since wùë§w is a constant and computing pairwise scores for m‚Äã(w‚àí1)ùëöùë§1m(w-1) records is at most O‚Äã(t‚Äã(f)‚Äãm2‚Äã(w‚àí1)2)ùëÇùë°ùëìsuperscriptùëö2superscriptùë§12O(t(f)m^{2}(w-1)^{2}). By definition, t‚Äã(f)ùë°ùëìt(f) is polynomial in mùëöm and w‚àí1ùë§1w-1 is constant.

Finally, recall that the decision version of maximum-score 2-ordering accepted as input a decision constant kùëòk. A valid solution must return True if a list with 2-score at least kùëòk exists, where kùëòk is a positive integer. Construct the decision constant k‚Ä≤superscriptùëò‚Ä≤k^{\prime} of the transformed problem instance using the equation below:

k‚Ä≤=T1+T2superscriptùëò‚Ä≤subscriptùëá1subscriptùëá2k^{\prime}=T_{1}+T_{2} (4)

Here, T1subscriptùëá1T_{1} and T2subscriptùëá2T_{2} are given by the equations below:

T1=m‚Äã(w‚àí12)‚Äã12‚Äã‚àëu=1m‚àëv=1mf‚Äã(ru,rv)subscriptùëá1ùëöbinomialùë§1212superscriptsubscriptùë¢1ùëösuperscriptsubscriptùë£1ùëöùëìsubscriptùëüùë¢subscriptùëüùë£T_{1}=m{w-1\choose 2}\frac{1}{2}\sum_{u=1}^{m}\sum_{v=1}^{m}f(r_{u},r_{v}) (5)
T2=k‚Äã(w‚àí1)subscriptùëá2ùëòùë§1T_{2}=k(w-1) (6)

We perform maximum-score w-ordering on this transformed problem instance, with the inputs being the constructed set of records SùëÜS, the scoring heuristic f‚Ä≤superscriptùëì‚Ä≤f^{\prime} and the decision constant k‚Ä≤superscriptùëò‚Ä≤k^{\prime}. We claim that the (True or False) output of the oracle solving the transformed problem is exactly the output of the original problem instance. In other words, we claim a correct Karp reduction.

We start by showing the correctness of the Karp reduction for the False output. We prove by contradiction that if the oracle return False, then it cannot be the case that an ordering of the original set RùëÖR of records exists, with 2-score at least kùëòk, assuming the score heuristic fùëìf.

Suppose not. That is, the oracle returned False but there is some ordering RlsuperscriptùëÖùëôR^{l} that has 2-score at least kùëòk. Without loss of generality, let Rl=<r1,‚Ä¶,rm>R^{l}=<r_{1},\ldots,r_{m}>. Since this list has 2-score at least kùëòk, the following is true:

‚àëi=1m‚àí1f‚Äã(ri,ri+1)‚â•k.superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëö1ùëìsubscriptùëüùëñsubscriptùëüùëñ1ùëò\sum_{i=1}^{m-1}f(r_{i},r_{i+1})\geq k. (7)

Given this information, consider (in the transformed problem) the list SlsuperscriptùëÜùëôS^{l} formed by concatenating the sub-lists S1l,‚Ä¶,SmlsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜ1ùëô‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùëÜùëöùëôS_{1}^{l},\ldots,S_{m}^{l}, where each SilsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùëñùëôS_{i}^{l} is simply <si1,‚Ä¶,siw‚àí1><s_{i}^{1},\ldots,s_{i}^{w-1}> for all iùëñi ranging over set IDs (that is, from 1 to mùëöm). Let us calculate the w-score of this list.

Since the window has size wùë§w while a sub-list has w‚àí1ùë§1w-1 records, it will be the case that each sub-list SlsuperscriptùëÜùëôS^{l} will fall entirely within some window, and therefore, all records within a sub-list will be paired and added to the (transformed problem) candidate set Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime}. Therefore, each sub-list, by itself, contributes exactly (w‚àí12)binomialùë§12{w-1\choose 2} pairs. Given Rule 1 in the construction of f‚Ä≤superscriptùëì‚Ä≤f^{\prime} and that there are exactly mùëöm sub-lists, the expression T1subscriptùëá1T_{1} (Equation 5) will be the score of all record pairs in Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime} such that both records in the pair are from the same sub-list.

Also, because of the way each sub-list is defined, it must be the case that in every window, exactly one pair of the form {sic,si+1c}superscriptsubscriptùë†ùëñùëêsuperscriptsubscriptùë†ùëñ1ùëê\{s_{i}^{c},s_{i+1}^{c}\} can contribute a non-zero score, among record pairs where both records are from different sub-lists. Consider Figure 4 for an illustration, with m=3ùëö3m=3 and w=4ùë§4w=4. Since cùëêc ranges from 1 to w‚àí1ùë§1w-1 and iùëñi ranges from 1 to m‚àí1ùëö1m-1, such pairs will contribute total score (using Rule 2):

T2‚Ä≤=(w‚àí1)‚Äã‚àëi=1m‚àí1f‚Äã(ri,ri+1)subscriptsuperscriptùëá‚Ä≤2ùë§1superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëö1ùëìsubscriptùëüùëñsubscriptùëüùëñ1T^{\prime}_{2}=(w-1)\sum_{i=1}^{m-1}f(r_{i},r_{i+1}) (8)

By Equations 6, 7 and 8, T2‚Ä≤‚â•T2subscriptsuperscriptùëá‚Ä≤2subscriptùëá2T^{\prime}_{2}\geq T_{2}. But this implies that the w-score of the constructed list Sl‚â•T1+T2superscriptùëÜùëôsubscriptùëá1subscriptùëá2S^{l}\geq T_{1}+T_{2}, which implies that the w-score is at least k‚Ä≤superscriptùëò‚Ä≤k^{\prime}, by Equation 4. This leads to a contradiction, since the oracle returned False. Thus, it must be the case that if a list with 2-score at least kùëòk exists in the original instance, a list with 2-score at least k‚Ä≤superscriptùëò‚Ä≤k^{\prime} exists in the transformed instance. By the contrapositive, the reduction is correct, assuming the oracle returns False.

In order to show the correctness of the oracle for a True output, we introduce some additional terminology. Define a list SlsuperscriptùëÜùëôS^{l} to be an interleaved list if there exist distinct records sicsuperscriptsubscriptùë†ùëñùëês_{i}^{c} and sidsuperscriptsubscriptùë†ùëñùëës_{i}^{d} in the list, such that the list contains, between these records, at least one record of the form sjesuperscriptsubscriptùë†ùëóùëís_{j}^{e} where i,j‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,m}ùëñùëó1‚Ä¶ùëöi,j\in\{1,\ldots,m\}, c,d,e‚àà{1,‚Ä¶,w‚àí1}ùëêùëëùëí1‚Ä¶ùë§1c,d,e\in\{1,\ldots,w-1\} and i‚â†jùëñùëói\neq j. Let a list that is not interleaved be defined as a stacked list. For example, the list in Figure 4 is stacked. The list in Figure 5 is interleaved.

Intuitively, a list is interleaved if records from some internal set SisubscriptùëÜùëñS_{i} are not all lined up against one another. Place each of |S|!ùëÜ|S|! orderings of SùëÜS into either the set of interleaved orderings ‚Ñêlsuperscript‚Ñêùëô\mathcal{I}^{l} or of stacked orderings ùíÆlsuperscriptùíÆùëô\mathcal{S}^{l}. Together, ‚Ñêlsuperscript‚Ñêùëô\mathcal{I}^{l} and ùíÆlsuperscriptùíÆùëô\mathcal{S}^{l} form a partition of the set of all orderings. Note that a stacked ordering is simply the concatenation of sub-lists, where each sub-list is of form SilsubscriptsuperscriptùëÜùëôùëñS^{l}_{i}, one of (w‚àí1)!ùë§1(w-1)! possible orderings of internal set SisubscriptùëÜùëñS_{i}.

Furthermore, define a stacked ordering to be aligned if the internal ID of the ct‚Äãhsuperscriptùëêùë°‚Ñéc^{th} record in every sub-list (with cùëêc ranging from 1 to w‚àí1ùë§1w-1) is the same. If a stacked ordering is not aligned, let it be denoted as unaligned. Figure 4 is an example of a stacked aligned ordering, while Figure 6 is an example of a stacked unaligned ordering. The set ùíÆlsuperscriptùíÆùëô\mathcal{S}^{l} is then partitioned into the sets ùíÆalsuperscriptsubscriptùíÆùëéùëô\mathcal{S}_{a}^{l} and ùíÆulsuperscriptsubscriptùíÆùë¢ùëô\mathcal{S}_{u}^{l} of stacked aligned and unaligned stacked orderings respectively.

Define the alignment function to be a function that takes a stacked unaligned ordering as input and aligns it by using a particular sub-list as a pivot. Thus, the output is a stacked aligned ordering. For example, Figure 4 is the alignment of Figure 6 if we use the first sub-list as the pivot. Specifically, the function rearranges the records in every sub-list except the pivot sub-list, such that the order of internal IDs in every sub-list now reflects the order of internal IDs in the pivot sub-list. Given that there can be at most mùëöm distinct pivot sub-lists for an unaligned ordering, the alignment function can yield at most mùëöm aligned orderings for a given input. We call this set of (at most mùëöm) possible alignments (for a given unaligned ordering SulsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùë¢ùëôS_{u}^{l}) the alignment set of SulsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùë¢ùëôS_{u}^{l}.

Using the concepts defined above, we state the following properties:

Property 1.

‚àÄIl‚àà‚Ñêl,‚àÄSl‚ààùíÆlformulae-sequencefor-allsuperscriptùêºùëôsuperscript‚Ñêùëôfor-allsuperscriptùëÜùëôsuperscriptùíÆùëô\forall I^{l}\in\mathcal{I}^{l},\forall S^{l}\in\mathcal{S}^{l}, w-score(IlsuperscriptùêºùëôI^{l}) ‚â§\leq w-score(SlsuperscriptùëÜùëôS^{l}).

Property 2.

‚àÄSul‚ààùíÆulfor-allsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùë¢ùëôsuperscriptsubscriptùíÆùë¢ùëô\forall S_{u}^{l}\in\mathcal{S}_{u}^{l}, the w-score of SulsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùë¢ùëôS_{u}^{l} will be no more than the w-score of any list in the alignment set of SulsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜùë¢ùëôS_{u}^{l}.

We do not provide technical proofs of these properties but they may be proved by contradiction, by calling on Rules 1 and 2 in the construction of f‚Ä≤superscriptùëì‚Ä≤f^{\prime}. Specifically, if the first property is false, it can be shown that Rule 1 was incorrectly applied, while if the second property is false, Rule 2 was incorrectly applied.

Intuitively, the first property holds because the score assigned to two records in the same internal set is ‚Äòtoo large‚Äô for Rule 2 to compensate for it171717Since, as we stated earlier, Rule 2 assigns only a specific entry in the f-matrix to an eligible pair, whereas Rule 1 assigns the sum of all entries in the f-matrix to an eligible pair. Recall that f was non-negative. It is always the case, in an interleaved list, that at least two records sharing the same set ID will not share a window at all. The second property holds for a similar reason (but with relation to Rules 2 and 3), when comparing a stacked unaligned ordering to its aligned version.

We prove the correctness of the oracle for True outputs by first observing that every stacked ordering (whether aligned or unaligned) is guaranteed to have w-score at least T1subscriptùëá1T_{1} (Equation 5), by an earlier part of the proof.

If an ordering with w-score at least k‚Ä≤superscriptùëò‚Ä≤k^{\prime} is interleaved, then every stacked ordering also has score at least k‚Ä≤superscriptùëò‚Ä≤k^{\prime} (Property 1). Consider a specific stacked aligned ordering that is the concatenation of sub-lists S1l,‚Ä¶,SmlsuperscriptsubscriptùëÜ1ùëô‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùëÜùëöùëôS_{1}^{l},\ldots,S_{m}^{l} and with records in each sub-list SilsubscriptsuperscriptùëÜùëôùëñS^{l}_{i} ordered as <si1,‚Ä¶,siw‚àí1><s^{1}_{i},\ldots,s^{w-1}_{i}>. We can follow the proof showing correctness of the oracle for False outputs backwards to derive Equation 7, which in turn, implies the existence of a 2-ordering with score at least kùëòk.

The same proof can be employed, with only a change in notation, if the ordering is not interleaved but is stacked and aligned. If the ordering is stacked and unaligned, we pick an element from the ordering‚Äôs alignment set (which has a w-score at least as high, by Property 2) and conduct the analysis in the previous sentence. In either case, Equation 7 will be the end result.

We conclude that the Karp reduction is correct. This proves the theorem that maximum-score w-ordering for any constant w>2ùë§2w>2 is NP-complete.

VI-C Proof of Theorem 5

By Theorem 1, we know that maximum-score 2-ordering each block individually is necessary and sufficient for achieving max SN, since Algorithm 3 assumes a local fùëìf. Suppose the w-score of the max list (the list on which max SN runs the merge step) is Œ¶‚àósuperscriptŒ¶\Phi^{*}. Before performing 2-ordering, we have a list of uùë¢u blocks, <Ry1,‚Ä¶,Ryu><R_{y_{1}},\ldots,R_{y_{u}}>, where each block is a set of records. Let the maximum score of a block yisubscriptùë¶ùëñy_{i} be Œ¶‚àó‚Äã[yi],‚àÄi‚àà{i,‚Ä¶,u}superscriptŒ¶delimited-[]subscriptùë¶ùëñfor-allùëñùëñ‚Ä¶ùë¢\Phi^{*}[y_{i}],\forall i\in\{i,\ldots,u\}. By Theorem 1 and because fùëìf is local, we have:

Œ¶‚àó=‚àëi=1uŒ¶‚àó‚Äã[yi]superscriptŒ¶superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùë¢superscriptŒ¶delimited-[]subscriptùë¶ùëñ\Phi^{*}=\sum_{i=1}^{u}\Phi^{*}[y_{i}] (9)

If we can prove an approximation ratio œÅùúå\rho for each Œ¶‚àó‚Äã[yi]superscriptŒ¶delimited-[]subscriptùë¶ùëñ\Phi^{*}[y_{i}], where œÅùúå\rho is the approximation ratio of MAX TOUR-TSP, then Equation 9 will prove the theorem.

We drop the second subscript and consider an arbitrary block RysubscriptùëÖùë¶R_{y} with |Ry|=msubscriptùëÖùë¶ùëö|R_{y}|=m records. In line 8 of Algorithm 3, the auxiliary subroutine RecordsToGraph converts RysubscriptùëÖùë¶R_{y} into a weighted, complete, undirected graph (with an extra dummy vertex). Consider again Figure 3. Since the problem is to find a tour, we can use the dummy vertex, without loss of generality, as the first and last vertex in the returned tour (by MAX TOUR-TSP) <dummy,e1,v1,‚Ä¶,vm,em+1,dummy><dummy,e_{1},v_{1},\ldots,v_{m},e_{m+1},dummy>. We adopt the usual notation that record risubscriptùëüùëñr_{i} was bijectively mapped to vertex visubscriptùë£ùëñv_{i}, with iùëñi ranging from 1 to mùëöm.

The main observation is that, regardless of whether the tour is optimal or not, any edge following or preceding the dummy vertex will always be 0 by construction, and will not contribute anything to the total tour weight. The difference (between the optimal and sub-optimal tour weights) can only be due to the path <v1,‚Ä¶,vm><v_{1},\ldots,v_{m}>. Let the same path in the optimal tour be denoted as p‚Äãa‚Äãt‚Äãh‚àóùëùùëéùë°superscript‚Ñépath^{*}. If the approximation ratio of the TSP algorithm is œÅùúå\rho, this implies that:

‚àëe‚ààE‚Äãd‚Äãg‚Äãe‚Äãs‚Äã(p‚Äãa‚Äãt‚Äãh)W‚Äã(e)‚àëe‚ààE‚Äãd‚Äãg‚Äãe‚Äãs‚Äã(p‚Äãa‚Äãt‚Äãh‚àó)W‚Äã(e)‚â•œÅsubscriptùëíùê∏ùëëùëîùëíùë†ùëùùëéùë°‚Ñéùëäùëísubscriptùëíùê∏ùëëùëîùëíùë†ùëùùëéùë°superscript‚Ñéùëäùëíùúå\frac{\sum_{e\in Edges(path)}W(e)}{\sum_{e\in Edges(path^{*})}W(e)}\geq\rho (10)

The TourToList subroutine in Algorithm 3 converts this inner path into the ordered list of records, as illustrated in Figure 3(b). Thus, the numerator in the summation above is exactly Œ¶‚Äã[y]Œ¶delimited-[]ùë¶\Phi[y] and the denominator is Œ¶‚àó‚Äã[y]superscriptŒ¶delimited-[]ùë¶\Phi^{*}[y]. This proves the theorem.

VI-D Construction showing score-decline of greedy adjacent swapping

We show a construction that proves that greedy adjacent swapping (GAS), described in Section V-C, does not always improve scores. The construction is shown in Figure 7. Although we only show the construction for forward pass, a symmetric case can be constructed for the backward pass.

Assuming w=2ùë§2w=2, the list on which the GAS procedure operates has each block maximum-score 2-ordered181818As an additional detail, list polarities are also correct, which is required by Algorithm 5. The correctness is evident since f‚Äã(4,5)>f‚Äã(4,8)ùëì45ùëì48f(4,5)>f(4,8) and f‚Äã(8,9)>f‚Äã(8,11)ùëì89ùëì811f(8,9)>f(8,11), which may be easily verified in Figure 7 by noting the score matrices for each block in Figure 8. The correctness of the GAS procedure itself can also be verified by using the given scores (in Figure 8) between records belonging to different blocks (inter-block scores in the figure). If we now perform merge and compute the candidate set score for the two lists in Figure 7 (before and after the GAS procedure was run), Œìo‚Äãr‚Äãi‚ÄãgsuperscriptŒìùëúùëüùëñùëî\Gamma^{orig} is found to have score 6+7+6+1+3=2367613236+7+6+1+3=23, where we break up the score by each block‚Äôs score (6, 6 and 3) and the scores contributed by records straddling adjacent blocks (7 and 1). Similarly, the candidate set score after GAS, ŒìG‚ÄãA‚ÄãSsuperscriptŒìùê∫ùê¥ùëÜ\Gamma^{GAS} is computed as 5+0+1+4+3=1350143135+0+1+4+3=13. The score has declined by a considerable margin.

To understand why such a decline occurred, consider the swap that took place in the second block. If after the first swap (of records 2 and 4 in Block 1), we would have computed the candidate set score, it would have increased, since the increase in score would have been f‚Äã(2,5)=9ùëì259f(2,5)=9 according to Figure 8 and the decline in the local 2-ordering score of Block 1 would only be 6‚àí5=16516-5=1. The global decline occurs because the first and last records in Block 2 end up getting swapped in the next step, which is a valid step according to GAS semantics. Because the procedure is greedy, it only takes into account the impact that the swap has on the local score of the current block. In other words, the ramifications on previous blocks are ignored.

Given that such declines can occur, we are therefore justified in comparing all three lists in line 7 of Algorithm 5.
